job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator I in Boston, MA
pros: Good for your resume if you can tolerate long enough
cons:
This is (of course) not reflective of all the jobs at UMassChan, but a specific department. There are a few other comments which I am guessing are referencing this position.  I knew this position had high turnover because my referral told me that quote “It’s been ridiculous how they can’t keep anybody for this.” . It only took me about a week or so of interacting with my new supervisor to figure out why. I thought I could deal with it, I was wrong. 

Both my current manager and the referral tried to drastically downplay the workload, the flexibility , and the expectations for this ‘part-time’ job. I regret trusting them during the interview process, but they were not honest or forthcoming. I chose to believe them when they said the hours are minimal and flexible. The expectations for a low paying and part time job are unrealistic. I had excellent references, and have several years of experience from another medical school, and never have I ever been so misled about what a position entails. My supervisor is rigid, micro-managing, gives extremely subjective and passive aggressive feedback, and is unable to see how they themselves are the problem with keeping part time staff. Despite getting highly referred and recommended to this position I couldn’t do it for more than 6 months. It just wasn’t sustainable. The work load and expectations were not practical for a part time position. They definitely downplayed it and weren’t honest during the interview process. I felt extremely misled.

pros: Commonwealth Medicine is the public service consulting and operations division of the UMass Medical School. The main pro of working at Commonwealth Medicine is the opportunity to partner with committed individuals making a difference in the lives of the less fortunate.
cons:
Make no mistake, as a division of the UMass Medical School, Commonwealth Medicine is a state agency. As such, you’ll find that the culture is heavily bureaucratic and you may face limited career growth and capped earnings. Many members of the leadership team at CWM come from state, hospital or nurse administration, rather than health care consulting, so you'll experience rigid, old school “command-and-control” supervision in many areas of the organization. 

Projects and employment can be very volatile due to a reliance on state budgets and state tax revenues. Technology and innovation lags the private sector due to red tape and tight budgets.

review_title: Great place to retire from but will do nothing to advance your career.
pros: Vacation benefits and lots of great people. You can't beat the commute if you are in Worcester County but you'll pay for parking!
cons:
Don't expect compensation or promotion for quality, hard work.  It occurs that both HR and upper management will attempt to block this from happening despite excellent yearly reviews, above and beyond quantity of work, and glowing recommendations from direct managers. There is no ladder.  Expect to stay in your same job and receive 2% raises most years for your entire time there.  There are so many people who do absolutely no work because there is no incentive. 
It's a huge blow to your team's morale and productivity.  Employees realize quickly that if they are good workers they will get lots of work, if they are lazy and unproductive they will get less work, raises will be the same. 
There is no communication between the people who make the decisions and the people who implement.  Expect short deadlines always, not because of decisions being made last minute but because of poor communication.

review_title: Commonwealth Medicine -- loss of the founder = politics and chaos
pros: UMMS and Commonwealth Medicine serve a noble cause: improved healthcare for Massachusetts residents, people across the US and around the globe.
cons:
The Commonwealth Medicine division of UMMS was founded by Tom Manning, a visionary and very effective leader who grew the organization to over $400 million in revenue (not for profit) with clients in many states and 20 countries around the globe.

Unfortunately, Tom resigned after Michael Collins was named the new Chancellor of UMMS.  Over investment in expensive lab space and personnel, combined with the impact of the Great Recession and NIH cuts finally hit, which led to rounds of layoffs.  Internal politics and ineffective business leadership became critical problems.  The collapse of the Massachusetts healthcare exchange was the most public failure; a UMMS team led this project.

Based on reviews from others about UMass Medical School itself, it appears that similar problems occurred there.

UMMS is a large and important organization.  Like an elephant, it can survive many blows that would take a smaller company, and State funding virtually guarantees that UMMS is here to stay.  That said, it will continue to struggle without stronger management and vision at every level.

job_title: Research Associate I in Worcester, MA
pros:
good benefits
good work-life balance
good diversity & inclusion
cons: can be a little difficult to negotiate substantial salary increases or promotions

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: great place with opportunities to learn and grow
cons: hard to find affordable housing

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator II in Worcester, MA
pros: Great benefits and the commute isn't like Bostons
cons: Pay less than some of their competitors

pros: Great community of researcher within UMass
cons: No other Uni /insti is around. Worcester has fewer job opportunities than Boston but cheaper.

review_title: Great place to study and work
pros: Friendly faculty, cutting-edge research, great learning environment
cons: Not much to do in Worcester

pros: Good training and experience for clinical responsibilities
cons: Dealing with hierarchy of medical system

pros: Too Many pros to list
cons: No social security benefits, pension

job_title: Clinical Research Assistant I in Worcester, MA
pros: its great, people are nice
cons: nothing, i have to work from home

pros: Great PTO and other governmental benefits
cons: Overworked and underpaid, multiple supervisors to report to

review_title: Well, no growth oppurtunties or career advancement
job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Worcester, MA
pros: None whatsoever, nothing to highlight
cons: No growth oppurtunties or career advancement, no benefits no employee match, expensive health insurance

pros: It is one of the top institutions in the medical research field in America and around the world . It is a great place to work and grow. I feel proud of this institution because its high quality of service and profesionalism. The enviroment is also very nice and comfortable. UMass  is located in a very convenient  spot to get to it. They take their job and mission very seriusly and that is an inspiring work place that I will love to work and be part of it. These reasons made UMass one of the most  high scale and prestigious institututions  that people will love to work for in USA and outside the country.
cons: Some of the research projects I worked weren´t submitted on time for continuation and get the grants on time. This situation was a great deal concerning for all the former employees.

pros: State employee benefits. Modern flexible schedule benefits. Good base salary. Accessible location. Free parking. Spacious accommodations. Good equipment and resources. Good balance of work to socialization. Eclectic staff. Important work is performed for an important organization. Most of the support staff are capable and responsive. Half of the leadership is excellent and competent.
cons: Disorganized cluster of programs who act like fiefdoms. Poor leadership. Poor Leadership to Employee communications. Culture changes frequently and without explanation. Blatant favoritism, intimidation, bullying. Popular opinion of under appreciation, poor staff utilization, and amateur management. Program staffers have become secondary to overpaid IT contractors who no one seems to know what they do or why they are present. Poor assistance from parent location.

review_title: "Great place if you're not a union employee"
pros: Work with a great group of people and they are very supportive. Good Benefits (be prepared to spend the money),
cons: Union employees (admins) are not allowed any extra compensation except what the union negotiates in the annual performance review contract. Ask for more money and/or title or grade change don't expect anything. If you want to advance in UMass as a union employee you need to apply for a position as a professional employee. Union employees don't get the same treatment but they do the same if not more work than some of the professional employees.  The department I am in the union employees are not recognized for advancement monetarily or otherwise.

review_title: Charlestown location is an unstable place to work
pros: Great benefits vacations and really high starting salaries. Lots of perks like reduced insurance and cell phone plans and flexible work schedules.
cons: This place operates on emotions and whether or not you are in the in crowd; Its worst than high school. There will be no career path or chance for advancement if they don't like you. The directors/managers are a tight knit group; they block you from moving to other departments by sharing their jaded opinions of staff with each other and basically blacklist you from other positions. This means if you are fed up with the way they treat you, your only recourse is the door.  For this reason the turnover rate is high. I would not recommend anyone leave a stable position to work at UMMS. It is an extremely difficult place to navigate.

review_title: Short stay at a place that needs a lot of work - the reviews are true
pros: People are generally very friendly around campus and at the hospital, great work/life balance, time off benefits are good.
cons: Management; people who’ve been hired who have no qualifications for the departments they’re (not) leading; lack of opportunity and challenging work; decisions are made without considering the people who are doing the work; hiring practices without core competencies to help weigh and select strong candidates who will contribute; red tape; employees who’ve done things one way for a long time so there can’t possibly be another way; leaders and teams who don’t collaborate; micromanagement; zero funds for professional development.

job_title: Contracted Research Assistant in Shrewsbury, MA
pros: flexible hours, personable and knowledgeable supervisors and staff, extensive training and practice, weekly phone conferences to discuss progress on project
cons: Not to many cons here, the commute was rough for me, so I would have to coordinated things with other staff members to avoid the 1.5 hour trip out to drop off paperwork. Most of my work was done in Boston though and not at the Shrewsbury site. The project I was working on was eventually defunded because of lack of participants which is a huge downside but the team tried to do everything in their power to recruit participants.

pros:
Strong Infrastructure, opportunity to implement your ideas. There are few good scientist .

Good seminar series in most of departments.
cons:
HR is big nuisance, totally inefficient, just know how to make weird rules without any in-depth knowledge.

They don;t know the difference between post-doc and Research associate. And even after many years of pos-doc experience, they will try to give you designation which is much lower paid then Research Associate and they defend this by saying that its based on experience which is totally absurd. 

Good place to be Research associate, where you will be entitled to automatic promotion after every 3 year with good raise and at after few years you will paid far better then senior level Pos-doc or Instructor.

review_title: PArt time is great, but management is weird
pros: Awesome school with a grand purpose and great people.  Love the feeling I am helping them in any way.  The people I work with are the farthest thing I know from the "walking-dead" state worker stereotype.  They'll give everything without complaint, if they need to.  And union jobs are the best, bar none.  I wish I learned thi before I turned 50
cons: Management is hard to figure out - one minute they are smart, the next they are saving $200 by not giving overtime and expecting people to catch drips in a bucket when the roof is gone.  Guess it has something to do with working on the cutting edge, for the state.

pros: Very good benefits. Very kind, hard-working and highly knowledgeable colleagues. Good work life balance. Mission-oriented work. Social justice orientation. Appreciation for diversity, a tolerant work place. My manager was very supportive of my professional growth. Varied work with opportunities to provide input to the future direction of my division/team. A lot of creative freedom into my work.
cons: Lack of Standard Operating Procedures and Project Management capacity at my division. At times waste and duplication of efforts. Poor communication / mixed messages from senior management as to direction of the division. Lack of a team-oriented culture; work is very silo-ed and sometimes isolating.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Worcester, MA
pros: The scientific community at UMass is one of the best, the people here are supportive, knowledgeable and very willing to collaborate. The research here is innovating and exciting, and you could not ask for a better environment to train as a scientist.
cons: Like most universities, postdoctoral fellowships come with a small salary and at UMass often fall below the NIH salary cap.  While there is great scientific mentoring, there is little room to grow and advance beyond the level of postdoc, and the career mentoring needs a boost. Also, the Chancellor could put more energy in promoting the research here instead of only  focusing on the Med School and translational science.

review_title: A great run while we had funding
job_title: Research Associate II in Worcester, MA
pros: UMass has a great work-life balance, benefits (vacation and sick time), and co-workers. Plenty of opportunities to learn new things. If you like working in a multi-cultural environment where cutting-edge science happens around you all the time, this is a great place to be. The people who work here really want to make a difference.
cons: If the lab is funded by grants, there is higher pressure for speedy results and publishable data. The compensation is not as much as industry.

pros: There is great potential for innovation and collaboration to happen! The community is passionate, friendly, and diverse which results in such an interdisciplinary environment. I found that I was never bored and the work was exciting. Benefits are good - there are plenty of coverage options, flexible time off, and plenty of vacation days.
cons: Transparency with management - I found that some issues about future direction and projects in my group were not addressed properly and left ambiguous. Management could take more time to connect with employees, develop trust, and create a closer work-relationship with them. Morale needs work however it is improving.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Worcester, MA
pros: People are always willing to teach you and you can learn new things. The school has a great reputation, so it will help you get employment at the school as a Post Doc or other companies throughout the country, especially Boston where the 2nd largest biotech hub is located.
cons: You have to find the right advisor for your learning style and personality. There can be difficult relationships between you and the advisor, it is difficult to get it sorted out if the PI has lots of friends on your committee. Each department has some politics that can affect your PI/advisor and inevitably, yourself.

review_title: Not the worst, but not the best!
pros: Great co-workers, good benefits, stable job, state employed. 8 hour shift and the occasional weekend for OT.
cons: Hard to move up, management doesn't care about it's employees, and the pay is pretty sad, but if you need a job then it'll do.  It was okay at the start, but it takes so long to move up the chain and even then, if the supervisors don't like you (for whatever reason, could be your hairstyle) you could be here 10+ years and not be promoted.  Or they have you doing jobs that are a higher pay grade, but won't get you the raise you deserve for doing that job.

review_title: Lots of new and strong leadership
pros: The environment is very collaborative, and many of its leaders are truly passionate about teaching, research and healthcare.  A number of new and innovative department chairs are making a tremendous effort to try new approaches.  If you are looking for somewhere to work that values new ideas, this is the place!  Also, the drive to Worcester is sooooo much easier than driving in towards Boston.
cons: Funding new ideas is always a challenge, and that is no different at UMass Medical School.  It's required being clever on a budget.

review_title: lack of funding brings down overall quality
pros: The research is great and one of the best in the world. Top notch scientists in an atmosphere that promotes sharing of ideas and cooperation.
cons: It seems the university is a bit low on funds, as they keep laying off staff such as the IT department. Building management staff has also been cut down and this leads to lots of work being left undone. The new building they made is not designed well, and keeps getting problem reports (noise, plumbing, vacuum fixtures, etc).

review_title: Experience as a postdoc will vary depending on dept and supervisor
pros: good benefits package - better than a lot of places since it's a public institution.  good support system with regards to foreign scholars, and there are a lot of good researchers here
cons: salaries (even those that are NIH guidelines) are guidelines only, it is apparently up to the discretion of the supervisor to follow them.  Some supervisors are there only to take advantage of the postdocs and do not care about their next steps, some go out of their way to help, but really, most do not.  Parking is terrible.

pros: There are a lot of nice hardworking people at the school. Campus is nice as are the benefits.
cons: Too often there is sideways movement due to arrogant members of management who are more focused on short-term what's in it for me rather than a more long-term holistic focus of what is good for the school. Politics overplay efficient execution and saving taxpayer money.

review_title: Nothing like it used to be
pros: None, unless you are one of the top paid management.
cons: Low pay for the work expected from you. Not given the salary that was originally offered. Understandably high turnover rate. Not clarified up front the number of people I would have to support even though the salary was greatly reduced and not enough hours in the day to support these many staff members. Management completely nonsupportive. Very high salaries provided to administrative staff as evidenced on the State employee pay scale website. Employees are charged to park at the same rate.Those who have connections get to park on the site regardless of their length of service.

job_title: Mid-level Professional (Non-management), Commonwealth Medicine in Shrewsbury, MA
pros: Good (state) benefits. Stable hours.
cons: I worked in the CWM division of the school. While on the surface, this appears to be a decent place to work, just walk in to any department to see the black cloud of low morale appear. The project expanding the school at the main campus went so far over budget that cutbacks and layoffs are becoming an everyday occurrence. And rather than cutting down on the crazy number of $100k+ salaried executives and senior management staff that do nothing but add layers of bureaucracy and red tape that constantly ties the hands of progress, UMMS likes to start with the little people, cutting employees who, despite having been loyal to the organization for 10+ years at peanut salaries and offered no opportunity for advancement, stuck it out. Over the years, any opportunities for professional development have been cut completely. Tuition is not free for employees (50% off). Free courses offered previously (PMP certification, Lean Six Sigma training, etc.) have all been cut from the budget. Being promoted into a management position is not going to happen. Ever. Internal promotion of that nature is rare. HR is detached from staff and do nothing to facilitate internal growth - internal applicants are treated the same way as if the organization had never met them before and they hadn't put in years of service. Most upper management staff are subject matter experts - not people managers and most lack the skills to effectively manage staff. Despite knowing this, there is no management training provided to new managers (that was cut too). This is a dead end employer. If you want to punch a time clock, keep your head down, sit in a cubicle all day and are not interested in advancing your career (maybe you're biding your last few years until retirement?), then this is the place for you. If you're interested in building a career, move along. Employees are made to feel untrustworthy and completely replaceable - your opinion is not valued. The South Street building is filled with people who are miserable and totally dead inside. It's not pretty.

pros: Work with some very bright people, dynamic environment with the opportunity to learn a lot of new technologies.
cons: IT group - Absolutely horrible management. - secretive, very little opportunity for advancement. Make too much money and you will have a target on your back. No recognition for the work you do, tons of school politics and state politics to navigate.

review_title: Doesnt follow FSLA minimum like other schools in the area like MIT/Harvard etc
pros: Nice environment with fewer crazy bosses. Not unhealthily competitive like the other big schools. Great career support for various alternative career pathways from the Center for Biomedical Career Development (led by a very enthusiastic and dedicated Cynthia Fuhrmann).
cons: UMass doesnt enforce the NIH recommended postdoc pay. It leaves it up to the PIs. This means that many PIs (mine included) don't pay NIH recommended postdoc salaries.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Worcester, MA
pros: There is good room for advancement.  Love the people who work there.  Very dedicated and the research is amazing.  Lots of great work being done there.
cons: If you aren't part of the in crowd, good luck.  Also, they don't tell you that if you retire as a state employee, you lose 2/3 of your social security.  You end up learning a lot through the grapevine.  Lots of backstabbing - sad, but true.

pros: Fantastic collaborative atmosphere. Great opportunities to branch out of departmental disciplines and apply methodologies and paradigms from other biomedical specialties. Competitive graduate student stipend. Very little politics and divisive management of projects within labs as a general policy.
cons: Lacks significant official coursework, so skill acquisition is very specific and self-determined. Not a great support system for career development outside of academia, though they are working on it.

review_title: I've worked in a lot of great places.  This wasn't one of them.
pros: You get a lot of vacation and sick time.  There's a lot of nice people, but only if you find yourself in the right unit or department.
cons: There's a very high turnover rate.  It's unfriendly towards teamwork or group activities.  Creativity is dead.  There's very little opportunity for growth or advancement.  And there's a level of discrimination towards race and gender that's somewhat apparent.

pros: A wonderful campus culture that's inspired by a noble mission in health care education and research. The Medical School is a thriving entity that feels more like a startup than it does a piece of the state university system.
cons: Located a good hour outside of Boston. It lacks the energy that you would experience being in the city or in Cambridge. Many of the local faculty, staff, and execs put on a "proud to be in Worcester" face, but you do feel like you are working in the shadow of a great big city.

pros: You get 4 weeks vacation so there's at least 4 weeks out of the year when you're not there
cons: This place is the definition of a toxic workplace. You walk down the halls and people aren't smiling. There seems to be a persistent drive towards to commoditization of the employees here, where there is increasing emphasis on the short term bottom line, rather than long term investments in the mission. There is a lack of communication when it comes to policy changes where employees are often not informed there has been a change until it is implemented and you spend as much time undoing things because of this as you do actually moving forward

review_title: It was an excellent opportunity to gain hands-on experience in scientific research.
pros: I had a huge amount of flexibility in my work hours, as well as helpful and thoughtful direction. It was a meaningful start for someone hoping to gain experience in scientific research, a field that is often difficult to gain entrance to. My mentors were always willing to coach me and answer questions, without being overbearing.
cons: It's not easy work—it requires both physical and mental dexterity as well as a talent for multitasking. There is certainly a learning curve and the margin for careless errors is quite small. But such is the nature of working in science.

pros: Benefits and medical insurance coverage are comparable however, they offer a lot of plan to choose from which sets them apart from other companies I have worked for.  Work/life balance is very good.
cons: Job security: Job is federal grant acquisition based and could end without notice or could end at the appointed time but if no new grant is acquired to replace the one ending, then layoffs occur.  Very hierarchical and employees are not empowered.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Worcester, MA
pros:
Once you accept the reality that, as a postdoc you are underpaid and undervalued, there are some advantages to working at UMMS. Your experience will vary depending on which professor you work for and the department. I had an excellent boss but the department could be pretty unpleasant. 

 Basically all newly minted PhDs have to spend 3-5 years (or more) as postdocs before getting a job that allows them to earn more than their cousin who works a toll booth. Nationwide, postdocs are less exploited than they have been in the past, but it's all relative. Postdoc is a training position after all, but the whole academic research system is a pyramid scheme so the number of jobs created pales compared to the avalanche of qualified scientists graduated each year. 

There's nothing really special about compensation.Salaries and benefits at UMMS are at the bare minimum levels allowed by NIH.
cons: Despite the fact that it's a public institution, UMMS aspires to be as rigid and cold-hearted as any ruthless corporation. I was working my tail off into the late hours on an important experiment on my last day so I didn't have the time to clean out my desk or say goodbye to people. My job essentially ended because we ran out of research funding for my position. Despite the fact that no one would need my desk, or locker, the administrators quickly wanted anything of mine removed from the premises. Quite a shock considering I still was on good terms with my boss and coworkers and would still be working to publish an article (without pay) and might have need of some resources.

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Worcester, MA
pros: Great working facilities.  The hours are flexable and there is a new gym facility open 24h a day.  The food provided is healthy and offers breakfast and lunch.
cons: The facility is located in Worcester, which does have its charm, but night life dosent just happen, you need to go out and find it.  The Gym does not have towel service, which is a bit of a pain.

review_title: The people I worked with were very competent and ethical people.  And they were friendly. Biomedical imaging research.
pros:
Good people.  Interesting research (breast cancer detection through PET Scanning).  My immediate boss and his boss were decent people - good to their employees.
You get to do interesting work and learn a lot.
cons: Funding depends on Government Grants, which are unpredictable.

pros: This is a great place to work for graduate or postdoctoral training. There are many wonderful scientists here and the scientific community as a whole is very collaborative and supportive. I think the graduate student and post-doc salaries are competitive and the health benefits are great.
cons: As in any research environment there is a lot of pressure to progress so sometimes it can be challenging to find a work life balance, but not impossible. I also feel that there is little room to advance for non-tenure track scientists.

pros: Good benefits with vacation, personal, and sick benefits.  Co-workers are nice most times.
cons: This position answers to everyone, so it's stressful and over-worked.  The pay is not the best for the amount of work you do and the amount of stress you feel.  Most need to do submissions and monitor post-award, which can be difficult when staffing is not brought in.

pros: Lots of vacation time and paid holidays, on site parking, cafeteria in the building
cons:
Management does not communicate with its employees and the disconnect can lead to feelings of chaos, and a sense that they are disinterested in improving skills of employees and recognizing their success. I'll echo what other reviewers of this location have said and say that favoritism is rampant in this office. If you are not part of the 'in' crowd and constantly tell your boss what they want to hear then you are not going to move forward.

There is only one annual review of employees by managers and vice versa which rarely offers constructive feedback. The office has no interest or intent on promoting from within which leads highly motivated and skilled employees to leave for greener pastures and the dead-weight employees that coast to stay here until pension time. The office does not offer any training programs or seminars to learn essential business skills. If you want to learn a technical program - that is crucial to your job - you have to pester a coworker to teach you on the side.

If a manager wants to promote an employee, the employee must formally apply for the position and go through HR checks (which focus almost solely on tenure and an archaic pay structure) and an interview process (with their own boss about the job that they are already doing). This process wastes the employee's time, the manager's time, and the time of prospective candidates. All for the sake of show. It normally takes 3 months of wading through red tape before the process is over.

Lastly, I work on a team of 6 people and our director has made 3 of my coworkers cry in the past 4 months and one of them quit.

pros: Paid holidays, vacation time, sick time, personal days (24hrs/year), family medical leave, other benefits.
cons:
You get paid biweekly
have to pay union fees biweekly
have to pay parking fees biweekly
Management in the dept I worked for did not communicate with each other, lots of miscommunication. One manager would tell me to do one thing then another would come and tell me to do another contradicting what the first said and in the end I would get in trouble for it.
Compensation it on a pay grade scale, reviews did not happen often.

pros: Office with a window and nearby restaurants.
cons: Incompetent leadership. "Good ole' boys club"mentality. Nepotism. Inappropriate behavior is rewarded. Useless "Office of Diversity and Inclusion" which is there ONLY to be politically correct. Favoritism. If you are Irish, related to someone in the state system or know someone in the state system you are a 'shoe-in'. Merit increases are based on how subservient one is willing to be. Merit increases are NOT based on merit. Misappropriation of funds/stealing. Immoral behavior is ignored. Plagiarism. Bullying. Corruption. Cultures and values: PHONY/Non-existent.

pros: I share the mission of the medical school. I love the educational programming. They make a big effort to make sure the students have a broad range of experiences.
cons: Some of the mid-level administration have been there too long. they end up negatively influencing the organization because they try to protect their fiefdom.

pros: Good health insurance and flexible time off, when needed. The DCAP and FSA are a tremendous help as is the Free Tuition at all State Universities and colleges.
cons: Absolutely no opportunity for advancement whatsoever. Poor, if any, raises, incredibly dissatisfied staff and low morale, with most people using their positions as, "stepping stones." With the exception of managers, people are paid poorly and have no interest in their job.

job_title: Information Technology Management in Worcester, MA
pros: UMMS is incredibly mission oriented. There is consistent, honest communication from senior leaders. There is no better industry to work in right now. UMMS is training the next generation of clinical leaders, researching novel therapies and supporting state healthcare programs.
cons: I thought working outside the Boston area would be a downside to this job, but it has been a bonus! Light traffic and a thriving downtown in Worcester are great.

pros: Great co-workers, fun atmosphere, employee benefits and programs are wonderful
cons: Middle management is terrible, and discrimination is evident.  Mgrs who treat others in an unacceptable fashion are Not disciplined (HR/Diversity dept is not doing their job)!  Dont work there unless you like to be verbally abused, bullied, discriminated against and then made to feel it was your fault!

job_title: Senior Solutions Architect in Charlestown, MA
pros:
Very easy atmosphere. (One note - I did work at the Charlestown / Schraffts office, which is a different segment than the rest of UMass Med. This review applies only to that IT area.)

Friendly, collegial, good benefits...
cons: Not a place to go if you wish to further your career! Few people care about the quality of their work, and most people look their job as "lifers". It can be very frustrating for people who care about project success, meeting deadlines, etc.

review_title: Great opportunities, but no work/life balance
pros: Fast paced environment, with lost of opportunities to collaborate with different departments. Not boring - something different to do everyday. Technology and equipment available on campus was extremely new/state of the art. Friendly coworkers and staff.
cons: Extremely demanding and sometimes very stressful; not rewarding. Often expected/required to come in super early, stay late, work on weekends without pay. Parking situation was also a bit of a hassle (had to be shuttled to campus from parking garage, would sometimes take 20+ minutes).

pros: State benefits are good to have, fairly easy job.
cons:
There is no such thing as career growth. Many people have been stuck in their current titles for many years without hope of a promotion or “moving up.” Many talented workers have left over the years either due to massive layoffs or because working here is terrible. Morale is near zero. 

Management loves to talk about tech buzzwords, bid ideas that we’re aiming towards, to seem like we’re cutting edge. But these things have little value to actual work, and it’s mostly a facade.

Management also picks favorites, including cases of hiring several former co-workers from a previous job over other applicants.

job_title: Research Assistant in Chevy Chase, MD
pros: Great place, great people. I really enjoyed working with the doctors, nurses, and medical students. Very demanding, but that's to be expected out of such a top rate institution
cons: Unpaid Internship. I put in a fair amount of work, but overall I lost money while working there. However, the people I worked under were understanding of this. Honestly, I don't mind working for free due to the experience and internship credit.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Worcester, MA
pros: Great place to get a PhD. It is a solid program with great resources and diverse faculty who are willing to chat with anyone. Worcester gets a bad wrap, but has a great set of bars with good beer.
cons: Worcester is up and coming, but lacks the variety of Boston.

pros: It's a project driven environment in the medical school. You will learn a lot hands on skills for doing practical research. The team I have been work with is productive.
cons: Don't expect too much  independent time for doing your own research is you don't have your own funding. The pay is in the lower part of the market, given the living cost of Worcester is fairly high. Gym, cafeteria are  terrible, benefits are so so.

job_title: Senior Systems Administration Engineer in Shrewsbury, MA
pros: Good salary for the area.  Pension benefit is good.  Great access to new technologies and a wide breadth of technologies.  Supporting medical research that can make a difference is more rewarding than working for a typical for profit corporation.
cons: Company charges for parking.  Politicking is required between managers and within groups.  Since the new CIO was hired there have been three rounds of layoffs.

pros: State job offers fantastic benefits - got to choose between about 9 different health insurances, 13 paid holidays a year, 4 wks vacation and 3 wks sick time. Relaxed atmosphere with flexible hours.
cons: In any lab, the person in charge is a scientist and not a manager. This leads to many problems with the daily running of the lab, executive decisions, hiring/firing, etc. There is very little room for growth without a PhD.

pros:
Great research environment with top notch faculty and science. There are multiple HHMI lab, a brand new research building and lots of funding. 

The medical has a great reputation and the medical students are very close and not competitive. Plus med school is affordable @ $50K/year
cons: The administration loves it's medical students and marginalized the Ph. D students. It's almost disgusting.

pros: Lots of vacation and holiday time. 10 years = vested = 80% of your healthcare paid by the state in your retirement. (If the benefit still exists.)
cons: Horrible, heavy politics. Raises that barely constitute cost of living raises regardless of outstanding reviews and work history.  No advancement opportunity. Many employees do very little work because there is no incentive or they are politically connected. Most stay to get their 10 years and be vested.

pros: supportive team environment, always new information to learn, knowledgeable and friendly leadership, the company values education and giving back to society, collaborative faculty, great benefits
cons: Management needs to provide more growth and learning opportunities, non-competitive salary, there is too much division between departments, poor IT support,

job_title: Senior Systems Administration Engineer in Shrewsbury, MA
pros: Lots of tech for an IT person to get their hands on.  Money is being invested in certain areas.
cons: Consistent management turnover with even more consistent worker level "layoffs".  I quote layoffs because it's not a cost saving measure, but just a nice way to circumvent their regular policy of paying appropriate severance.  Like many situations with large management turnover, the sycophants quickly rise up the ranks.  Don't be realistic if you want to succeed here; only unrealistic optimism and fake smiles win the day.  Partnerships flounder (DCO and hosted email) in the mean time.

review_title: Really good place to work if you get the right manager/department
pros: Known to offer Great compensation and benefits, the latest technology and the best of resources for its employees.  There are really great health and retirement benefits.
cons: There is the union that you have to deal with and HR appears to work for themselves.  HR was very accommodating when I got hired and quite ruthless when my job got cut.

pros: 403B, health care insurance, paid time off, some flexibility in work schedule, purposeful work. My manager gave me a lot of responsibility and time for special projects that helped me further develop my skills.
cons: During my time at UMass I noticed some upper management drama with in the department and also a noticeable occurrence of lay offs, seemed to be waves of lay offs across all of UMass for a while.

job_title: Research Coordinator I in Worcester, MA
pros: Great coworkers and supervisor, great experience, great connections. Results will vary GREATLY depending on what lab you join as the majority of the labs have their own way of doing things.
cons: UMass' Med School building is a bit old and dull. If you're working an office/lab it can be somewhat of a bland environment unless you're in a new building.

job_title: Data Management in Jamaica Plain, MA
pros: Standard benefits and competitive pay.
cons: Doctors in charge are snoots and creeps, cliquey with certain lab techs, some of who were trying to unionize. I was harassed on the job and put on paid suspension based on anonymous complaints. I was terminated after my lawyer contacted them for refusing my request for a copy of my employee file as required by law. Filed a complaint with MCAD and they didn't challenge my unemployment claim. The woman directly responsible for my suspension and termination is no longer employed with UMMS.

review_title: People are Great, benefits and pay are poor
pros: The community and people I work with in my lab are great. Everyone gets along really well and communicate well with each other.
cons: UMass requires experience to be at UMass for it to count towards a salary bump. My starting salary was exactly the same as I made with my BS. They don't reward for a MS degree.

review_title: Continued IT layoffs make job more stressful than it should be
pros:
-Benefits and time off
-Some new technologies being introduced
cons:
-Big layoffs and random layoffs (person here and there) have resulted in a lot  of good people leaving. 
-Pay below market for private sector.
-IT Management is not good.

review_title: Good place to work, but not for growth.
pros: great benefits. work hours good and flexible.  health benefits , PTO etc are all good.
cons: not too much movement with promotions or bonuses . they are far and few in between.

job_title: Neonatal Intensive Care Unit, Research Associate in Worcester, MA
pros: I love the environment in a clinical setting. I have been working here for more than a year and everyone is nice and friendly. I have a flexible schedule. Nurses and Doctors are always willing to help.
cons: I don't see any cons in my current job.

review_title: All elements of UMass Worcester are in disarray.
pros: Some middle management and line staff still care.
cons: Understaffed in all areas, this campus is being run like a high-tech startup. State benefits are waning and staff cuts are frequent, especially just before each new fiscal year.

review_title: Work at UMass as a researcher
pros:
Quality and diversity of science
Lots of quality speakers every week
Equipment
Core services
cons:
Life in Worcester (weather, lack of cultural activity)
Not a lively campus (absence of undergrads, no cafe/bar where people can informally gather)
Poor Human Resources department
Lack of an organized post-doctoral program
Lack of protection for international students and staff (few resources do deal with abusive bosses, for instance)

review_title: Boring and unsafe town, bad management
pros: Some laboratories conduct cutting edge scientific researches (but most other labs aren't doing well). Medical students have all the support from the school.
cons:
1. Major focus on medical students and MDs; they have almost all the resources. 
2. Research part isn't too strong. Many labs are poorly managed. 
3. HR said their job is to protect the school not the employees.
4. Worcester is a small and boring town with low ethnic diversity and high crime rate.

review_title: Good people, but lots of turnover
